@himanshug this changes default behavior. If people want the behavior of reporting uncovered intervals, then they need to set a new configuration option

Prior to this patch: return uncovered intervals (or try to)

With this patch: Do not return uncovered intervals

With this patch AND `uncoveredIntervalsLimit` : return uncovered intervals (or try to)

@himanshug this fails UT

Spoke with @b-slim about this PR. Here are some major points in this PR that need addressed:
- Add note in PR master comment that hits PR is promoting QTL state to first class druid state object. And the proposed manager to be the manager for that state.
- Expectations on registration behavior and process need clarified in concrete docs (probably in the manager class's javadoc)
- LookupExtractor state lifecycle needs managed in consistent way and clear documentation on what those expectations are.
- Proposed lookup state registration method eliminates the capacity to pass query time parameters to the LookupExtractor. For example: current namespace lookup extension allows the parameters `replaceMissingValueWith` and `retainMissingValue` at query time. The proposed management paradigm does not allow for usage of any such parameters. Or more specifically, requires registration of a new LookupExtractor for any unique combination of parameters.

@xvrl @fjy 
I have do some performance with the flowing query:

```
{
  "queryType": "topN",
  "dataSource": "dataSource",
  "dimension": "query",
  "metric": "pv",
  "threshold": 10,
  "granularity": "day",
  "postAggregations": [],
  "aggregations": [
    {
      "name": "pv",
      "fieldName": "pv",
      "type": "longSum"
    }
  ],
  "intervals":["2015-01-01/2100-01-01"]
}
```

The segment have 6622769 number row, 'query' column cardinality is 3132475. I do run 100 round and the average time is:
Before the patch **4442** ms
After the patch **4474** ms
@CHOIJAEHONG1 This is the intended behavior. Segments in Druid are always v9 before they can be queried.

I thought that when `buildV9Directly` is set to false, v8 is to be built and then we convert it into v9 manually using a convert task.

By the way, I found this while trying to build a v8 segment to test this code below which appears not to work right when a metric is a type of LONG. I was able to produce a v8 segment and got the result of all zeros querying on it. Of source this version of segment would be destined to disappear I guess.
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexIO.java#L952
Ah, sorry. I've confused with other issue.
I will open a separate PR for the issue related to LONG type.

@CHOIJAEHONG1 the intended behavior of `buildV9Directly` set to false is that segments are built as v8 first but then immediately converted to v9 before being published. So either way you would get a v9 segment, the only difference is how it is built.
I'm working on this one with @pjain1 , so assigning it to him.
One thing that wasn't clear from the group thread, are you planning on having all auth information in headers, or will it require parsing the message body?
Interestingly, https://travis-ci.org/druid-io/druid/jobs/105678550 said it failed, but the logs have no actual failure
This will need to be reconciled with https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1849

@binlijin did you look at what I did in #1849 before working on this?
My experience is that guava cache might have worse latencies, that's why I haven't been gung ho on getting #1849 merged.

Also note https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1836

There seem to be a few outstanding issues with the caching done currently that are not called out here:
1. Latency of guava cache
2. Benchmarks on concurrent access
3. Improvements (or no change) on behavior of large single-scans clobbering the cache.

Note that https://github.com/acesinc/druid-cors-filter-extension is essentially a servlet extension. If you find some stuff that works well or that needs to change to make druid servlet extensions work well, it would be worth notifying them about.
:+1: after travis

If I'm reading this correctly, the intended behavior with this patch is that `stopGracefully`can be called AND THEN the task object can still function.

given the contract on `stopGracefully` is 

```
Asks a task to arrange for its "run" method to exit promptly. This method will only be called if
   * {@link #canRestore()} returns true. Tasks that take too long to stop gracefully will be terminated with
   * extreme prejudice.
```

This seems like unexpected behavior for a task to have.

@drcrallen this patch is fixing the case where the task has started running, but then someone calls `stopGracefully` before the firehose has connected (which happens during `run`).

It does work too even if you call stopGracefully before run, but that's mostly to make the test easier to write. That's definitely not intended real world usage.

Given this is a bug fix, and doesn't modify behavior in a significant way that isn't part of the bug (and extra synchronization which looks benign), I'm :+1: 

But at this point it looks like it would be worth adding in a state ENUM instead of the expanding quantity of booleans.

The class is starting to get a bit unwieldy.
agree that a state enum would be better.

@drcrallen @xvrl can you take a look at  https://github.com/ben-manes/concurrentlinkedhashmap ？

@himanshug

> It appears that the performance improvement is proposed by...

Yes, major points are from the direct conversion of id[] to index[]. And also we don't need interning Strings before adding to fact. 

> shared lock object in DimDim

By using int[] instead of string[], we need more frequent access to converting id back to value, which is `DimDim#getValue(int id)`. It was implemented by synchronized bimap and I thought it just can be an List which seemed more faster than map. So additional lock is introduced to guard two collections.

> and DimensionHolder

removed that.
